title: Route Methods
ques: How do you define a route that handles a **POST** request to `/users`?
explanation: Express has methods for all HTTP verbs: `app.get()`, `app.put()`, `app.delete()`.

title: Route Parameters
ques: How do you capture a **dynamic parameter** (like an ID) from the URL `/users/123`?

answer.content:
You define the route with a colon: `app.get('/users/:id', ...)`.

You access the value via **`req.params`**.
`const userId = req.params.id;`

explanation: `req.params` contains route parameters; `req.query` contains URL query string parameters (`?id=123`).

title: Wildcard Route
ques: How do you create a 'Catch-All' route (for 404 pages) that matches **everything**?
explanation: This must be placed **after** all other routes, otherwise it will match everything before the specific routes can run.

title: Express Router
ques: As your app grows, why should you use **`express.Router()`**?

answer.content:
**`express.Router()`** allows you to create modular, mountable route handlers.

**Benefit:** Instead of putting 50 routes in `app.js`, you can create a `users.js` router file and a `posts.js` router file, and mount them: `app.use('/users', userRouter);`.

explanation: It helps organize your application into mini-applications.
